verses.text: By the rivers of Babylon we sat and wept when we remembered Zion.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 137
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 137 Of all the psalms this is probably the most clearly related to a historical event, the Exile of Judah to Babylon in the sixth century b.c. There is conflicting evidence about whether the psalm was composed during the Exile or immediately afterward (v. 1 note). The despair experienced in the Exile is eloquently expressed along with anger toward the enemy (vv. 7–9).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 137:1
rsbNotes.text:
137:1 the waters of Babylon. The Tigris and Euphrates as well as numerous canals flowed near Babylon, far from Zion and the temple.

we sat down and wept. These words express the deep despair caused by deportation and exile.

Zion. See Ps. 2:6; 50:2; 65:1; 74:2; 128:5; 129:5.

verses.text: There on the poplars we hung our harps,

rsbNotes.title: Ps 137:2
rsbNotes.text: 137:2 lyres. Instruments of joy. After a victory Israel responded with songs (Ex. 15; Judg. 5). In defeat, the music ceases and there is silence (Is. 24:8, 9).

verses.text: for there our captors asked us for songs, our tormentors demanded songs of joy; they said, "Sing us one of the songs of Zion!"
How can we sing the songs of the LORD while in a foreign land?

rsbNotes.title: Ps 137:3
rsbNotes.text:
137:3 our captors. The Babylonians.

one of the songs of Zion. These are songs such as Ps. 46 and 48, about the greatness of Zion and Jerusalem. With Jerusalem destroyed, the Babylonians ridiculed their captives.

verses.text: If I forget you, O Jerusalem, may my right hand forget its skill.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 137:5
rsbNotes.text: 137:5 my right hand forget. How to play the harp. If he cannot sing of Jerusalem, he will not sing at all.

verses.text: May my tongue cling to the roof of my mouth if I do not remember you, if I do not consider Jerusalem my highest joy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 137:6
rsbNotes.text: 137:6 my highest joy. Now that Christ has come, there are no special holy places, but during the period of the Psalms there was but one—Zion. Jerusalem symbolically represented the City of God, composed of all believers (Gal. 4:26; Rev. 21:9–27). For the exiles, not only religious but political and cultural feelings were evoked by thoughts of their homeland.

verses.text: Remember, O LORD, what the Edomites did on the day Jerusalem fell. "Tear it down," they cried, "tear it down to its foundations!"

rsbNotes.title: Ps 137:7
rsbNotes.text: 137:7 Remember . . . the Edomites. Obadiah testifies to the callousness and hostility of the Edomites when Jerusalem fell to the Babylonians.

verses.text: O Daughter of Babylon, doomed to destruction, happy is he who repays you for what you have done to us-

rsbNotes.title: Ps 137:8
rsbNotes.text: 137:8 daughter of Babylon. A personification of the nation of Babylon.

verses.text: he who seizes your infants and dashes them against the rocks.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 137:9
rsbNotes.text: 137:9 dashes . . . against the rock. See Is. 13:16; Hos. 13:16; Nah. 3:10. On this cry for retributive justice see Introduction: The Curses of the Psalms.
